mn148:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn148:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn148:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

mn148:2.1.pli: “dhammaṃ vo, bhikkhave, desessāmi ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāsessāmi, yadidaṃ—
mn148:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, I shall teach you the Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And I shall reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure, namely,
mn148:2.1.comm: While this description of the Dhamma is frequently found, it is not elsewhere used as an introduction to a specific teaching.

mn148:2.3.pli: Taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
mn148:2.3.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

mn148:2.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

mn148:3.1.pli: “Cha ajjhattikāni āyatanāni veditabbāni, cha bāhirāni āyatanāni veditabbāni, cha viññāṇakāyā veditabbā, cha phassakāyā veditabbā, cha vedanākāyā veditabbā, cha taṇhākāyā veditabbā.
mn148:3.1.eng: “The six interior sense fields should be understood. The six exterior sense fields should be understood. The six classes of consciousness should be understood. The six classes of contact should be understood. The six classes of feeling should be understood. The six classes of craving should be understood.

mn148:4.1.eng: ‘The six interior sense fields should be understood.’

mn148:4.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
mn148:4.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

mn148:4.3.pli: Cakkhāyatanaṃ, sotāyatanaṃ, ghānāyatanaṃ, jivhāyatanaṃ, kāyāyatanaṃ, manāyatanaṃ.
mn148:4.3.eng: There are the sense fields of the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

mn148:4.4.eng: ‘The six interior sense fields should be understood.’

mn148:4.5.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn148:4.5.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

mn148:4.6.eng: This is the first set of six.

mn148:5.1.eng: ‘The six exterior sense fields should be understood.’

mn148:5.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
mn148:5.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

mn148:5.3.pli: Rūpāyatanaṃ, saddāyatanaṃ, gandhāyatanaṃ, rasāyatanaṃ, phoṭṭhabbāyatanaṃ, dhammāyatanaṃ.
mn148:5.3.eng: There are the sense fields of sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas.

mn148:5.4.eng: ‘The six exterior sense fields should be understood.’

mn148:5.5.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn148:5.5.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

mn148:5.6.eng: This is the second set of six.

mn148:6.1.eng: ‘The six classes of consciousness should be understood.’

mn148:6.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
mn148:6.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

mn148:6.3.pli: Cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ,
mn148:6.3.eng: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights.

mn148:6.4.pli: sotañca paṭicca sadde ca uppajjati sotaviññāṇaṃ,
mn148:6.4.eng: Ear consciousness arises dependent on the ear and sounds.

mn148:6.5.pli: ghānañca paṭicca gandhe ca uppajjati ghānaviññāṇaṃ,
mn148:6.5.eng: Nose consciousness arises dependent on the nose and smells.

mn148:6.6.pli: jivhañca paṭicca rase ca uppajjati jivhāviññāṇaṃ,
mn148:6.6.eng: Tongue consciousness arises dependent on the tongue and tastes.

mn148:6.7.pli: kāyañca paṭicca phoṭṭhabbe ca uppajjati kāyaviññāṇaṃ,
mn148:6.7.eng: Body consciousness arises dependent on the body and touches.

mn148:6.8.pli: manañca paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manoviññāṇaṃ.
mn148:6.8.eng: Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and ideas.

mn148:6.9.eng: ‘The six classes of consciousness should be understood.’

mn148:6.10.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn148:6.10.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

mn148:6.11.eng: This is the third set of six.

mn148:7.1.eng: ‘The six classes of contact should be understood.’

mn148:7.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
mn148:7.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

mn148:7.3.pli: Cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ, tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso;
mn148:7.3.eng: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact.

mn148:7.4.pli: sotañca paṭicca sadde ca uppajjati sotaviññāṇaṃ, tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso;
mn148:7.4.eng: Ear consciousness arises dependent on the ear and sounds. The meeting of the three is contact.

mn148:7.5.pli: ghānañca paṭicca gandhe ca uppajjati ghānaviññāṇaṃ, tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso;
mn148:7.5.eng: Nose consciousness arises dependent on the nose and smells. The meeting of the three is contact.

mn148:7.6.pli: jivhañca paṭicca rase ca uppajjati jivhāviññāṇaṃ, tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso;
mn148:7.6.eng: Tongue consciousness arises dependent on the tongue and tastes. The meeting of the three is contact.

mn148:7.7.pli: kāyañca paṭicca phoṭṭhabbe ca uppajjati kāyaviññāṇaṃ, tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso;
mn148:7.7.eng: Body consciousness arises dependent on the body and touches. The meeting of the three is contact.

mn148:7.8.pli: manañca paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manoviññāṇaṃ, tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.
mn148:7.8.eng: Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and ideas. The meeting of the three is contact.

mn148:7.9.eng: ‘The six classes of contact should be understood.’

mn148:7.10.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn148:7.10.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

mn148:7.11.eng: This is the fourth set of six.

mn148:8.1.eng: ‘The six classes of feeling should be understood.’

mn148:8.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
mn148:8.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

mn148:8.3.pli: Cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ, tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso, phassapaccayā vedanā;
mn148:8.3.eng: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact. Contact is a requirement for feeling.

mn148:8.4.pli: sotañca paṭicca sadde ca uppajjati sotaviññāṇaṃ, tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso, phassapaccayā vedanā;
mn148:8.4.eng: Ear consciousness arises dependent on the ear and sounds. The meeting of the three is contact. Contact is a requirement for feeling.

mn148:8.5.pli: ghānañca paṭicca gandhe ca uppajjati ghānaviññāṇaṃ, tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso, phassapaccayā vedanā;
mn148:8.5.eng: Nose consciousness arises dependent on the nose and smells. The meeting of the three is contact. Contact is a requirement for feeling.

mn148:8.6.pli: jivhañca paṭicca rase ca uppajjati jivhāviññāṇaṃ, tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso, phassapaccayā vedanā;
mn148:8.6.eng: Tongue consciousness arises dependent on the tongue and tastes. The meeting of the three is contact. Contact is a requirement for feeling.

mn148:8.7.pli: kāyañca paṭicca phoṭṭhabbe ca uppajjati kāyaviññāṇaṃ, tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso, phassapaccayā vedanā;
mn148:8.7.eng: Body consciousness arises dependent on the body and touches. The meeting of the three is contact. Contact is a requirement for feeling.

mn148:8.8.pli: manañca paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manoviññāṇaṃ, tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso, phassapaccayā vedanā.
mn148:8.8.eng: Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and ideas. The meeting of the three is contact. Contact is a requirement for feeling.

mn148:8.9.eng: ‘The six classes of feeling should be understood.’

mn148:8.10.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn148:8.10.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

mn148:8.11.eng: This is the fifth set of six.

mn148:9.1.eng: ‘The six classes of craving should be understood.’

mn148:9.2.pli: iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiñcetaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ?
mn148:9.2.eng: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?

mn148:9.3.pli: Cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ, tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso, phassapaccayā vedanā, vedanāpaccayā taṇhā;
mn148:9.3.eng: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact. Contact is a requirement for feeling. Feeling is a requirement for craving.
mn148:9.3.comm: We have now included the six sense fields, contact, feeling, and craving, which are four of the items of dependent origination.

mn148:9.4.pli: sotañca paṭicca sadde ca uppajjati sotaviññāṇaṃ …pe…

mn148:9.5.pli: ghānañca paṭicca gandhe ca uppajjati ghānaviññāṇaṃ …

mn148:9.6.pli: jivhañca paṭicca rase ca uppajjati jivhāviññāṇaṃ …

mn148:9.7.pli: kāyañca paṭicca phoṭṭhabbe ca uppajjati kāyaviññāṇaṃ …

mn148:9.8.pli: manañca paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manoviññāṇaṃ, tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso, phassapaccayā vedanā, vedanāpaccayā taṇhā.
mn148:9.8.eng: Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and ideas. The meeting of the three is contact. Contact is a requirement for feeling. Feeling is a requirement for craving.

mn148:9.9.eng: ‘The six classes of craving should be understood.’

mn148:9.10.pli: iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
mn148:9.10.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

mn148:9.11.eng: This is the sixth set of six.

mn148:10.1.pli: ‘Cakkhu attā’ti yo vadeyya taṃ na upapajjati.
mn148:10.1.eng: If anyone says, ‘the eye is self,’ that is not tenable.
mn148:10.1.comm: This is an unusual use of na upapajjati in the sense, “is not tenable”, “does not obtain”, or “is not justified”.

mn148:10.2.eng: The arising and vanishing of the eye is evident,

mn148:10.3.pli: Yassa kho pana uppādopi vayopi paññāyati, ‘attā me uppajjati ca veti cā’ti iccassa evamāgataṃ hoti.
mn148:10.3.eng: so it would follow that one’s self arises and vanishes.

mn148:10.4.eng: That’s why it’s not tenable to claim that

mn148:10.6.eng: So the eye is not self.

mn148:10.7.pli: ‘Rūpā attā’ti yo vadeyya taṃ na upapajjati.
mn148:10.7.eng: If anyone says, ‘sights are self,’ that is not tenable.

mn148:10.8.eng: The arising and vanishing of sights is evident,

mn148:10.9.pli: Yassa kho pana uppādopi vayopi paññāyati, ‘attā me uppajjati ca veti cā’ti iccassa evamāgataṃ hoti.
mn148:10.9.eng: so it would follow that one’s self arises and vanishes.

mn148:10.10.eng: That’s why it’s not tenable to claim that

mn148:10.12.eng: So the eye is not self and sights are not self.

mn148:10.13.pli: ‘Cakkhuviññāṇaṃ attā’ti yo vadeyya taṃ na upapajjati.
mn148:10.13.eng: If anyone says, ‘eye consciousness is self,’ that is not tenable.

mn148:10.14.eng: The arising and vanishing of eye consciousness is evident,

mn148:10.15.pli: Yassa kho pana uppādopi vayopi paññāyati, ‘attā me uppajjati ca veti cā’ti iccassa evamāgataṃ hoti.
mn148:10.15.eng: so it would follow that one’s self arises and vanishes.

mn148:10.16.eng: That’s why it’s not tenable to claim that

mn148:10.18.pli: Iti cakkhu anattā, rūpā anattā, cakkhuviññāṇaṃ anattā.
mn148:10.18.eng: So the eye, sights, and eye consciousness are not self.

mn148:10.19.pli: ‘Cakkhusamphasso attā’ti yo vadeyya taṃ na upapajjati.
mn148:10.19.eng: If anyone says, ‘eye contact is self,’ that is not tenable.

mn148:10.20.eng: The arising and vanishing of eye contact is evident,

mn148:10.21.pli: Yassa kho pana uppādopi vayopi paññāyati, ‘attā me uppajjati ca veti cā’ti iccassa evamāgataṃ hoti.
mn148:10.21.eng: so it would follow that one’s self arises and vanishes.

mn148:10.22.eng: That’s why it’s not tenable to claim that

mn148:10.24.pli: Iti cakkhu anattā, rūpā anattā, cakkhuviññāṇaṃ anattā, cakkhusamphasso anattā.
mn148:10.24.eng: So the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact are not self.

mn148:10.25.pli: ‘Vedanā attā’ti yo vadeyya taṃ na upapajjati.
mn148:10.25.eng: If anyone says, ‘feeling is self,’ that is not tenable.

mn148:10.26.eng: The arising and vanishing of feeling is evident,

mn148:10.27.pli: Yassa kho pana uppādopi vayopi paññāyati, ‘attā me uppajjati ca veti cā’ti iccassa evamāgataṃ hoti.
mn148:10.27.eng: so it would follow that one’s self arises and vanishes.

mn148:10.28.eng: That’s why it’s not tenable to claim that

mn148:10.30.pli: Iti cakkhu anattā, rūpā anattā, cakkhuviññāṇaṃ anattā, cakkhusamphasso anattā, vedanā anattā.
mn148:10.30.eng: So the eye, sights, eye consciousness, eye contact, and feeling are not self.

mn148:10.31.pli: ‘Taṇhā attā’ti yo vadeyya taṃ na upapajjati.
mn148:10.31.eng: If anyone says, ‘craving is self,’ that is not tenable.

mn148:10.32.eng: The arising and vanishing of craving is evident,

mn148:10.33.pli: Yassa kho pana uppādopi vayopi paññāyati, ‘attā me uppajjati ca veti cā’ti iccassa evamāgataṃ hoti.
mn148:10.33.eng: so it would follow that one’s self arises and vanishes.

mn148:10.34.eng: That’s why it’s not tenable to claim that

mn148:10.36.pli: Iti cakkhu anattā, rūpā anattā, cakkhuviññāṇaṃ anattā, cakkhusamphasso anattā, vedanā anattā, taṇhā anattā.
mn148:10.36.eng: So the eye, sights, eye consciousness, eye contact, feeling, and craving are not self.

mn148:11.1.eng: If anyone says, ‘the ear is self’ …

mn148:11.5.pli: ‘mano attā’ti yo vadeyya taṃ na upapajjati.
mn148:11.5.eng: ‘the mind is self,’ that is not tenable.

mn148:11.6.eng: The arising and vanishing of the mind is evident,

mn148:11.7.pli: Yassa kho pana uppādopi vayopi paññāyati, ‘attā me uppajjati ca veti cā’ti iccassa evamāgataṃ hoti.
mn148:11.7.eng: so it would follow that one’s self arises and vanishes.

mn148:11.8.eng: That’s why it’s not tenable to claim that

mn148:11.10.eng: So the mind is not self.

mn148:12.1.pli: ‘Dhammā attā’ti yo vadeyya taṃ na upapajjati.

mn148:12.3.pli: Yassa kho pana uppādopi vayopi paññāyati, ‘attā me uppajjati ca veti cā’ti iccassa evamāgataṃ hoti.

mn148:13.1.pli: ‘Manoviññāṇaṃ attā’ti yo vadeyya taṃ na upapajjati.

mn148:13.3.pli: Yassa kho pana uppādopi vayopi paññāyati, ‘attā me uppajjati ca veti cā’ti iccassa evamāgataṃ hoti.

mn148:13.6.pli: Iti mano anattā, dhammā anattā, manoviññāṇaṃ anattā.

mn148:14.1.pli: ‘Manosamphasso attā’ti yo vadeyya taṃ na upapajjati.

mn148:14.3.pli: Yassa kho pana uppādopi vayopi paññāyati, ‘attā me uppajjati ca veti cā’ti iccassa evamāgataṃ hoti.

mn148:14.6.pli: Iti mano anattā, dhammā anattā, manoviññāṇaṃ anattā, manosamphasso anattā.

mn148:15.1.pli: ‘Vedanā attā’ti yo vadeyya taṃ na upapajjati.

mn148:15.3.pli: Yassa kho pana uppādopi vayopi paññāyati, ‘attā me uppajjati ca veti cā’ti iccassa evamāgataṃ hoti.

mn148:15.6.pli: Iti mano anattā, dhammā anattā, manoviññāṇaṃ anattā, manosamphasso anattā, vedanā anattā.

mn148:15.7.pli: ‘Taṇhā attā’ti yo vadeyya taṃ na upapajjati.
mn148:15.7.eng: ‘craving is self,’ that is not tenable.

mn148:15.8.eng: The arising and vanishing of craving is evident,

mn148:15.9.pli: Yassa kho pana uppādopi vayopi paññāyati, ‘attā me uppajjati ca veti cā’ti iccassa evamāgataṃ hoti.
mn148:15.9.eng: so it would follow that one’s self arises and vanishes.

mn148:15.10.eng: That’s why it’s not tenable to claim that

mn148:15.12.pli: Iti mano anattā, dhammā anattā, manoviññāṇaṃ anattā, manosamphasso anattā, vedanā anattā, taṇhā anattā.
mn148:15.12.eng: So the mind, ideas, mind consciousness, mind contact, feeling, and craving are not self.

mn148:16.1.pli: Ayaṃ kho pana, bhikkhave, sakkāyasamudayagāminī paṭipadā—
mn148:16.1.eng: Now, mendicants, this is the way that leads to the origin of substantial reality.

mn148:16.2.pli: cakkhuṃ ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti samanupassati;
mn148:16.2.eng: You regard the eye like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’

mn148:17-21.1.pli: rūpe ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti samanupassati;

mn148:17-21.2.pli: cakkhuviññāṇaṃ ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti samanupassati;

mn148:17-21.3.pli: cakkhusamphassaṃ ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti samanupassati;

mn148:17-21.4.pli: vedanaṃ ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti samanupassati;

mn148:17-21.5.pli: taṇhaṃ ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti samanupassati;
mn148:17-21.5.eng: craving like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’

mn148:17-21.6.pli: sotaṃ ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti samanupassati …pe…

mn148:17-21.7.pli: ghānaṃ ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti samanupassati …pe…

mn148:17-21.8.pli: jivhaṃ ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti samanupassati …pe…

mn148:17-21.9.pli: kāyaṃ ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti samanupassati …pe…

mn148:17-21.10.pli: manaṃ ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti samanupassati, dhamme ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti samanupassati, manoviññāṇaṃ ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti samanupassati, manosamphassaṃ ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti samanupassati, vedanaṃ ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti samanupassati, taṇhaṃ ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti samanupassati.
mn148:17-21.10.eng: mind … ideas … mind consciousness … mind contact … feeling … craving like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’

mn148:22.1.pli: Ayaṃ kho pana, bhikkhave, sakkāyanirodhagāminī paṭipadā—
mn148:22.1.eng: But this is the way that leads to the cessation of substantial reality.

mn148:22.2.pli: cakkhuṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti samanupassati.
mn148:22.2.eng: You regard the eye like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

mn148:23-27.1.pli: Rūpe ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti samanupassati.

mn148:23-27.2.pli: Cakkhuviññāṇaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti samanupassati.

mn148:23-27.3.pli: Cakkhusamphassaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti samanupassati.

mn148:23-27.4.pli: Vedanaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti samanupassati.

mn148:23-27.5.pli: Taṇhaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti samanupassati.
mn148:23-27.5.eng: craving like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

mn148:23-27.6.pli: Sotaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti samanupassati …pe…

mn148:23-27.7.pli: ghānaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti samanupassati …pe…

mn148:23-27.8.pli: jivhaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti samanupassati …pe…

mn148:23-27.9.pli: kāyaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti samanupassati …pe…

mn148:23-27.10.pli: manaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti samanupassati.
mn148:23-27.10.eng: mind like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

mn148:23-27.11.pli: Dhamme ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti samanupassati.

mn148:23-27.12.pli: Manoviññāṇaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti samanupassati.

mn148:23-27.13.pli: Manosamphassaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti samanupassati.

mn148:23-27.14.pli: Vedanaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti samanupassati.

mn148:23-27.15.pli: Taṇhaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti samanupassati.
mn148:23-27.15.eng: craving like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

mn148:28.1.pli: Cakkhuñca, bhikkhave, paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ, tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso, phassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā.
mn148:28.1.eng: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact. Contact is a requirement for the arising of what is felt as pleasant, painful, or neutral.
mn148:28.1.comm: Literally, “With contact as dependency arises what is felt …”

mn148:28.2.pli: So sukhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
mn148:28.2.eng: When you experience a pleasant feeling, if you approve, welcome, and keep clinging to it,

mn148:28.3.eng: the underlying tendency to greed underlies that.

mn148:28.4.pli: Dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno socati kilamati paridevati urattāḷiṃ kandati sammohaṃ āpajjati.
mn148:28.4.eng: When you experience a painful feeling, if you sorrow and wail and lament, beating your breast and falling into confusion,

mn148:28.5.eng: the underlying tendency to repulsion underlies that.

mn148:28.6.pli: Adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno tassā vedanāya samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
mn148:28.6.eng: When you experience a neutral feeling, if you don’t truly understand that feeling’s origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape,

mn148:28.7.eng: the underlying tendency to ignorance underlies that.

mn148:28.8.pli: So vata, bhikkhave, sukhāya vedanāya rāgānusayaṃ appahāya dukkhāya vedanāya paṭighānusayaṃ appaṭivinodetvā adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya avijjānusayaṃ asamūhanitvā avijjaṃ appahāya vijjaṃ anuppādetvā diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro bhavissatīti—netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mn148:28.8.eng: Mendicants, without giving up the underlying tendency to greed for pleasant feeling, without dispelling the underlying tendency to repulsion towards painful feeling, without eradicating ignorance in the case of neutral feeling, without giving up ignorance and without giving rise to knowledge, it is quite impossible to make an end of suffering in this very life.

mn148:29-33.1.pli: Sotañca, bhikkhave, paṭicca sadde ca uppajjati sotaviññāṇaṃ …pe…

mn148:29-33.2.pli: ghānañca, bhikkhave, paṭicca gandhe ca uppajjati ghānaviññāṇaṃ …pe…

mn148:29-33.3.pli: jivhañca, bhikkhave, paṭicca rase ca uppajjati jivhāviññāṇaṃ …pe…

mn148:29-33.4.pli: kāyañca, bhikkhave, paṭicca phoṭṭhabbe ca uppajjati kāyaviññāṇaṃ …pe…

mn148:29-33.5.pli: manañca, bhikkhave, paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manoviññāṇaṃ, tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso, phassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā.
mn148:29-33.5.eng: Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and ideas. The meeting of the three is contact. Contact is a requirement for the arising of what is felt as pleasant, painful, or neutral.

mn148:29-33.6.pli: So sukhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
mn148:29-33.6.eng: When you experience a pleasant feeling, if you approve, welcome, and keep clinging to it,

mn148:29-33.7.eng: the underlying tendency to greed underlies that.

mn148:29-33.8.pli: Dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno socati kilamati paridevati urattāḷiṃ kandati sammohaṃ āpajjati.
mn148:29-33.8.eng: When you experience a painful feeling, if you sorrow and wail and lament, beating your breast and falling into confusion,

mn148:29-33.9.eng: the underlying tendency to repulsion underlies that.

mn148:29-33.10.pli: Adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno tassā vedanāya samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
mn148:29-33.10.eng: When you experience a neutral feeling, if you don’t truly understand that feeling’s origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape,

mn148:29-33.11.eng: the underlying tendency to ignorance underlies that.

mn148:29-33.12.pli: So vata, bhikkhave, sukhāya vedanāya rāgānusayaṃ appahāya dukkhāya vedanāya paṭighānusayaṃ appaṭivinodetvā adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya avijjānusayaṃ asamūhanitvā avijjaṃ appahāya vijjaṃ anuppādetvā diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro bhavissatīti—netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mn148:29-33.12.eng: Mendicants, without giving up the underlying tendency to greed for pleasant feeling, without dispelling the underlying tendency to repulsion towards painful feeling, without eradicating ignorance in the case of neutral feeling, without giving up ignorance and without giving rise to knowledge, it is quite impossible to make an end of suffering in this very life.

mn148:34.1.pli: Cakkhuñca, bhikkhave, paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ, tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso, phassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā.
mn148:34.1.eng: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact. Contact is a requirement for the arising of what is felt as pleasant, painful, or neutral.

mn148:34.2.pli: So sukhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
mn148:34.2.eng: When you experience a pleasant feeling, if you don’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to it,

mn148:34.3.eng: the underlying tendency to greed does not underlie that.

mn148:34.4.pli: Dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno na socati na kilamati na paridevati na urattāḷiṃ kandati na sammohaṃ āpajjati.
mn148:34.4.eng: When you experience a painful feeling, if you don’t sorrow or wail or lament, beating your breast and falling into confusion,

mn148:34.5.eng: the underlying tendency to repulsion does not underlie that.

mn148:34.6.pli: Adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno tassā vedanāya samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
mn148:34.6.eng: When you experience a neutral feeling, if you truly understand that feeling’s origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape,

mn148:34.7.eng: the underlying tendency to ignorance does not underlie that.

mn148:34.8.pli: So vata, bhikkhave, sukhāya vedanāya rāgānusayaṃ pahāya dukkhāya vedanāya paṭighānusayaṃ paṭivinodetvā adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya avijjānusayaṃ samūhanitvā avijjaṃ pahāya vijjaṃ uppādetvā diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro bhavissatīti—ṭhānametaṃ vijjati.
mn148:34.8.eng: Mendicants, after giving up the underlying tendency to greed for pleasant feeling, after dispelling the underlying tendency to repulsion towards painful feeling, after eradicating ignorance in the case of neutral feeling, after giving up ignorance and giving rise to knowledge, it’s quite possible to make an end of suffering in this very life.

mn148:35.1.pli: Sotañca, bhikkhave, paṭicca sadde ca uppajjati sotaviññāṇaṃ …pe….

mn148:36.1.pli: Ghānañca, bhikkhave, paṭicca gandhe ca uppajjati ghānaviññāṇaṃ …pe….

mn148:37.1.pli: Jivhañca, bhikkhave, paṭicca rase ca uppajjati jivhāviññāṇaṃ …pe….

mn148:38.1.pli: Kāyañca, bhikkhave, paṭicca phoṭṭhabbe ca uppajjati kāyaviññāṇaṃ …pe….

mn148:39.1.pli: “Manañca, bhikkhave, paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manoviññāṇaṃ tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso, phassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā.
mn148:39.1.eng: Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and ideas. The meeting of the three is contact. Contact is a requirement for what is felt as pleasant, painful, or neutral.

mn148:39.2.pli: So sukhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
mn148:39.2.eng: When you experience a pleasant feeling, if you don’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to it,

mn148:39.3.eng: the underlying tendency to greed does not underlie that.

mn148:39.4.pli: Dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno na socati na kilamati na paridevati na urattāḷiṃ kandati na sammohaṃ āpajjati.
mn148:39.4.eng: When you experience a painful feeling, if you don’t sorrow or wail or lament, beating your breast and falling into confusion,

mn148:39.5.eng: the underlying tendency to repulsion does not underlie that.

mn148:39.6.pli: Adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno tassā vedanāya samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
mn148:39.6.eng: When you experience a neutral feeling, if you truly understand that feeling’s origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape,

mn148:39.7.eng: the underlying tendency to ignorance does not underlie that.

mn148:39.8.pli: So vata, bhikkhave, sukhāya vedanāya rāgānusayaṃ pahāya dukkhāya vedanāya paṭighānusayaṃ paṭivinodetvā adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya avijjānusayaṃ samūhanitvā avijjaṃ pahāya vijjaṃ uppādetvā diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro bhavissatīti—ṭhānametaṃ vijjati.
mn148:39.8.eng: Mendicants, after giving up the underlying tendency to greed for pleasant feeling, after dispelling the underlying tendency to repulsion towards painful feeling, after eradicating ignorance in the case of neutral feeling, after giving up ignorance and giving rise to knowledge, it’s quite possible to make an end of suffering in this very life.

mn148:40.1.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako cakkhusmiṃ nibbindati, rūpesu nibbindati, cakkhuviññāṇe nibbindati, cakkhusamphasse nibbindati, vedanāya nibbindati, taṇhāya nibbindati.
mn148:40.1.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, sights, eye consciousness, eye contact, feeling, and craving.

mn148:41.1.eng: They grow disillusioned with the ear …

mn148:41.5.pli: manasmiṃ nibbindati, dhammesu nibbindati, manoviññāṇe nibbindati, manosamphasse nibbindati, vedanāya nibbindati, taṇhāya nibbindati.
mn148:41.5.eng: mind, ideas, mind consciousness, mind contact, feeling, and craving.

mn148:41.6.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati, virāgā vimuccati. Vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
mn148:41.6.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When it is freed, they know it is freed.

mn148:41.7.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
mn148:41.7.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

mn148:41.8.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn148:41.9.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn148:41.9.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.

mn148:41.10.pli: Imasmiṃ kho pana veyyākaraṇasmiṃ bhaññamāne saṭṭhimattānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ anupādāya āsavehi cittāni vimucciṃsūti.
mn148:41.10.eng: And while this discourse was being spoken, the minds of sixty mendicants were freed from defilements by not grasping.
mn148:41.10.comm: This is not found in parallel passages and is probably a later addition.
